quizzes.question: Type in the function that must be called before working with the session variables.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Sessions[/h1]

Using a [b]session[/b], you can store information in variables, to be used across multiple pages.
Information is not stored on the user's computer, as it is with [b]cookies[/b].
By default, session variables last until the user closes the browser.

[h2]Start a PHP Session[/h2]

A session is started using the [b]session_start()[/b] function.
Use the PHP global [b]$_SESSION[/b] to set session variables. [code format="php"]<?php
// Start the session
[b]session_start();[/b]

$_SESSION['color'] = "red";
$_SESSION['name'] = "John";
?>[/code]
Now, the [b]color[/b] and [b]name[/b] session variables are accessible on multiple pages, throughout the entire session.
[note]The [b]session_start()[/b] function must be the very first thing in your document. Before any HTML tags.[/note]

quizzes.question: Rearrange the code to declare the variable name, add it to the session, and then print it to the screen.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Session Variables[/h1]

[b]Another page[/b] can be created that can access the session variables we set in the previous page: [code format="php"]<?php
// Start the session
session_start();
?>
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<body>
<?php
echo "Your name is " . [b]$_SESSION['name'][/b];
// Outputs "Your name is John"
?>
</body>
</html>[/code]
[note]Your session variables remain available in the [b]$_SESSION [/b]superglobal until you close your session.
All global session variables can be removed manually by using [b]session_unset()[/b]. You can also destroy the session with [b]session_destroy()[/b]. [/note]
